title: Manchester City must take maximum points from Chelsea clash â€“ Gareth Taylor
body_text:
Manchester City must take maximum points from Chelsea clash â€“ Gareth Taylor
Manchester City manager Gareth Taylor has stressed the importance of â€œtaking maximum pointsâ€ ahead of a huge top-of-the-table clash against defending champions Chelsea in the Womenâ€™s Super League.
City are currently third in the table, two places and two points behind the Blues, who sit at the top of the summit.
Neither side has lost a WSL game since September last year and Cityâ€™s last league loss came against Chelsea at Kingsmeadow.
But with seven games left in the league, the title and a spot in next seasonâ€™s Champions League are still up for grabs and Taylor insists his side are aware of the challenges Chelsea pose.
â€œWe know the importance of the game, we worked so hard to get ourselves into this position,â€ the City boss told a pre-match press conference.
â€œObviously, itâ€™s a tough opponent in front of us. An opponent that had a successful result away at the European champions in midweek, so we understand the challenge in front of us.
â€œBut we are confident in what we do in terms of imposing ourselves on the game.
â€œBut we also know itâ€™s really important for us to take maximum points from this game. Itâ€™s a really important one for us to win to be able to continue in our challenge this season.
â€œWe have to win every game â€“ 21 points takes us to 56. Thatâ€™s what Chelsea won the league with last season.
â€œChelsea can go to 61 if they win all their games. So it just goes to show, if we win this game at the weekend nothing changes, we have to win the one after and the one after that.
â€œThe margins are so tight. Weâ€™ve lost two games this season, two draws. Arsenal have done that, (second-placed) Manchester United have done that.
â€œChelsea are the only ones who have only dropped five points, so itâ€™s so tight. Youâ€™ve got to win all your games, itâ€™s as simple as that.â€
Sunday caps off â€œWomenâ€™s Football Weekendâ€ and other fixtures include bottom-of-the-table Leicester facing a tricky test against an in-form Aston Villa side, who are currently on a seven-game unbeaten run in all competitions.

The fight for survival at the bottom of the table sees second-bottom Brighton travel to Reading in the other fixture on Sunday and Chelsea manager Emma Hayes believes the Womenâ€™s Football Weekend has been â€œa real hitâ€.
She told a press conference: â€œWomenâ€™s Football Weekend I think is becoming a staple on the calendar and to think so many games are being played across the country able to be accessed by football fans up and down.
â€œI think having these weekends in menâ€™s international breaks has been a real hit in the WSL and weâ€™re looking forward to build on the previous womenâ€™s football weekends and looking forward to hopefully see record numbers come out.â€
